title: Timing in the art of integration: 'that's how the Bastille got stormed'
abstract: This paper was originally presented at th ACM SIGGROUP conference on Supporting group work, 2005, Sanibel Island, Florida, USA.
rawRecordXml:
<record><header><identifier>
oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/8413</identifier><datestamp>2008-08-13T09:53:02Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_687</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>Timing in the art of integration: 'that's how the Bastille got stormed'</dc:title><dc:creator>Martin, David</dc:creator><dc:creator>Rouncefield, Mark</dc:creator><dc:creator>O'Neill, Jacki</dc:creator><dc:creator>Hartswood, Mark</dc:creator><dc:creator>Randall, David</dc:creator><dc:subject>Integration</dc:subject><dc:subject>Electronic patient records</dc:subject><dc:subject>Healthcare</dc:subject><dc:subject>COTS systems</dc:subject><dc:subject>Ethnography</dc:subject><dc:subject>Ethnomethodology</dc:subject><dc:subject>Configuration</dc:subject><dc:description>This paper uses a long term ethnographic study of the design and
implementation of an electronic patient records (EPR) system in a
UK hospital Trust to consider issues arising in the multi-faceted
process of integration when a customizable-off-the-shelf (COTS)
system is configured and deployed in a complex setting. The
process involves trying to artfully work out how disparate
technologies integrate with existing and evolving patterns of work
within developing regulatory requirements. We conclude by
suggesting ways in which ethnographic interventions and user
involvement may be timed and targeted to aid in achieving this
process.</dc:description><dc:description>This paper was originally presented at th ACM SIGGROUP conference on Supporting group work, 2005, Sanibel Island, Florida, USA.</dc:description><dc:publisher>ACM Press</dc:publisher><dc:date>2007-02-14T16:27:09Z</dc:date><dc:type>Article</dc:type><dc:format>YES</dc:format><dc:identifier>Proceedings of the 2005 international ACM SIGGROUP conference on Supporting group work, pp. 313-322</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>1595932232</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>10.1145/1099203.1099256</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/8413</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://delivery.acm.org/10.1145/1100000/1099256/p313-martin.pdf?key1=1099256&key2=3899641711&coll=portal&dl=ACM&CFID=15151515&CFTOKEN=6184618</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
subject: Article
